cards.productDescription: In our brand-new 135-page publication exclusively for supporting subscribers, we reveal point by point how a court led by a celebrated ‚Äúmoderate‚Äù like John Roberts has become the most extreme in a century ‚Äî and what can be done to stop it.

sections: With so much at stake in Tuesday‚Äôs midterms, we are putting You Love To See It on hiatus this weekend, to provide you with this important election story.

Leonard Leo, the conservative activist and architect of the current Supreme Court, has been relatively quiet this election cycle. But now, Iowans are now getting a firsthand look at how the conservative legal activist and his allies intend to use their billions of dollars in dark money to influence elections and crush efforts to protect consumers. Read
, from Andrew Perez, in full below.
will be livestreaming as the midterm election results roll in. As soon as the polls close, David Sirota and
‚Äôs reporters will be offering their analysis and commentary on the results ‚Äî and corporate media‚Äôs response to those results. They‚Äôll also be taking questions from the audience LIVE on-air.

exposed the largest political advocacy donation in U.S. history ‚Äî a mammoth $1.6 billion donation to a dark money group led by Leonard Leo, who as former President Donald Trump‚Äôs judicial adviser helped build the Supreme Court‚Äôs conservative supermajority to overturn federal protections for abortion rights.

Leo‚Äôs dark money network has been relatively quiet this election cycle, but Iowans are now getting a firsthand look at how the conservative legal activist and his allies intend to use their spoils to influence elections and crush efforts to protect consumers ‚Äî such as taking the sort of financial misconduct accusations usually aimed at their allies and throwing them back at Democrats.

In September, Leo‚Äôs dark money network registered a new fictitious entity, called the Alliance for Consumers Action Fund. The alliance soon began running TV ads in Iowa attacking the state‚Äôs Democratic attorney general, Tom Miller, over his role as chairman of the National Association of Attorneys General (NAAG). According to AdImpact, the group has reserved $93,000 worth of ads against Miller, who is up for re-election next week.

Their message is quite jarring: ‚ÄúConsumers are hurting, but Attorney General Tom Miller isn't helping,‚Äù the ad says. ‚ÄúA Miller-run group took $280 million from consumer protection cases. Miller isn't sending that money to victims. He's using it for A-list trips to London, and stashing it in overseas investments. Miller's operation has been called a racket. It needs to stop. Tell Tom Miller: No more overseas trips and foreign investments. Give the money back to victims here in Iowa.‚Äù

There‚Äôs some irony to the accusation, given that Leo‚Äôs network has long been the top funder of the Republican Attorneys General Association, which critics have decried as a corporate ‚Äúpay-to-play‚Äù operation.

NAAG, a century-old, non-partisan forum for state attorneys general, collects funds from settlement agreements between attorneys general and companies. A $574 million agreement with the consulting firm McKinsey & Co. for helping fuel the opioid crisis sent $15 million to NAAG. The association and its Mission Foundation

, the funds from settlements are used to support litigation assistance. ‚ÄúNAAG assists us in protecting constituents by funding conferences, training, and grants for investigations,‚Äù Miller said in August. ‚ÄúThis is how our offices hold people accountable, from small-time scammers to big tech companies and opioid makers and distributors.‚Äù
Leo‚Äôs Concord Fund ‚Äî a dark money nonprofit that led the media campaigns to confirm Leo‚Äôs Supreme Court picks under Trump ‚Äî
the Alliance for Consumers Action Fund as a trade name on September 19, according to Virginia corporate records. The alliance
its ad campaign targeting Miller ten days later.

‚ÄúOur first ad campaign to educate everyday consumers about NAAG kicked off in Iowa because Iowa Attorney General Tom Miller is currently in charge of NAAG,‚Äù O.H. Skinner, the alliance‚Äôs executive director, told
in an email, adding that ‚Äúthis is the beginning, not the end of our NAAG-related efforts.‚Äù
Skinner, as the head of an affiliated nonprofit, called the Alliance for Consumers, has been criticizing NAAG since March 2021.

‚ÄúInstead of sending money to victims, the McKinsey deal starts off with the type of arrangement only a politician could love ‚Äî $15 million to the nonprofit National Association of Attorneys General, known as NAAG,‚Äù he

. ‚ÄúAmongst other things, NAAG hosts events across the country for state attorneys general and their staff, culminating in an annual Capital Forum in December just down the street from the White House, with the D.C. political class in attendance.‚Äù
This criticism has been echoed by Republican attorneys general. Kentucky Attorney General Daniel Cameron (R) and seven other GOP attorneys general wrote a
to NAAG in May this year calling for ‚Äúgreater transparency prior to NAAG receiving, holding, and expending certain kinds of funds.‚Äù

The letter continued: ‚ÄúNAAG‚Äôs $15 million McKinsey settlement is nearly double the amounts received by some states and nearly 40 percent more than Kentucky received. These states have lost thousands of their citizens to the opioid epidemic and represent thousands more who still struggle. Yet NAAG, an entity with no such constituency, collected $15 million.‚Äù
The Cameron letter was amplified in a
in July entitled, ‚ÄúThe Attorneys General Racket.‚Äù The Alliance for Consumers Action Fund used this headline in its Iowa ad.

Leo has long sought to shape policy through state attorney general offices. His Concord Fund is consistently the top financier of the Republican Attorneys General Association (RAGA), which elects GOP attorneys general, alongside corporate donors. The Concord Fund has donated $3.5 million to RAGA this election cycle, according to data from
Republican attorneys general have played a crucial role in advancing Leo‚Äôs conservative agenda at the Supreme Court ‚Äî bringing and backing blockbuster cases like
Dobbs v. Jackson Women‚Äôs Health Organization
and allowed states to ban abortions again, as well as putting forward efforts to limit and overturn environmental protections.
Lisa Graves, executive director of the watchdog True North Research, called RAGA a ‚Äúquintessential pay-to-play group,‚Äù where
based on how much money they donate. With RAGA, GOP attorneys general ‚Äúare going on vacations, going to resorts, [and] letting companies tell them what their priorities are,‚Äù she said.

One way that Republican attorneys general have looked to cozy up to industry is by defanging their offices‚Äô consumer protection and environmental divisions, as former attorneys general and high-level staffers who became lobbyists

Graves said the Alliance for Consumers Action Fund is a way for Leo to ‚Äúsupport the right wing AGs and push their agenda and attack their opponents, Democratic attorneys general who have done public interest litigation and tried to hold corporations accountable.‚Äù
that his group will continue to attack NAAG: ‚ÄúWe aren‚Äôt going to stop until consumers win this fight over the money at NAAG.‚Äù
